title: 107_s335
content: The "Setting Aside for a Valuable Education (SAVE) Act" allows for the exclusion from gross income of education distributions from qualified state tuition programs. The "Setting Aside for a Valuable Education (SAVE) Act" amends section 529(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code to specify that distributions for qualified higher education expenses are not included in gross income, whether in-kind or cash distributions. The "SAVE Act" amends section 529(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude distributions for qualified higher education expenses from gross income, with exceptions for institutional programs before January 1, 2004. The "SAVE Act" modifies section 529(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude distributions for qualified higher education expenses from gross income, except for distributions under a qualified State tuition program before January 1, 2004. Any benefit provided to a designated beneficiary in a qualified State tuition program is considered a distribution to the beneficiary. The qualified higher education expenses for an individual in a taxable year shall be reduced as provided in section 25A(g)(2) and by the amount of expenses already used to determine the credit allowed under section 25A. Coordination with education savings accounts is also considered. The taxpayer must allocate qualified higher education expenses among distributions to determine the exclusion amount under specific clauses and sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency with education savings accounts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new sections related to education savings accounts. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2000. SEC. 3. Eligible educational institutions allowed to maintain qualified tuition programs. Section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow eligible educational institutions to establish and maintain qualified tuition programs. Private qualified tuition programs are limited to benefit plans, with additional requirements for certain programs established by eligible educational institutions. Under Section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code, eligible educational institutions can establish qualified tuition programs. To qualify, the program must have a trust created solely for paying the beneficiary's higher education expenses, with safeguards ensuring contributions are used for this purpose. The trust must also meet specific requirements regarding trustees and beneficiaries. The trust established under Section 529 must be managed by a trustee who complies with the requirements, ensures assets are not mixed with other property, and provides annual reports on the trust's financial condition. The trust must obtain an actuarial report to ensure sufficient assets to cover obligations and provide annual reports to contributors and beneficiaries. It also needs a favorable IRS ruling to confirm compliance. Before entering into contracts or accepting contributions, the trust must solicit ruling requests from the SEC regarding Federal securities laws compliance. The text discusses the requirements for qualified tuition programs under Federal securities laws, including conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to the headings and table of sections in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding qualified tuition programs. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 4. Other modifications to qualified tuition programs. Section 529(c)(3)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow rollovers to different qualified tuition programs for the same beneficiary, with a limitation of one transfer per year. Section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include first cousins as members of the family for educational savings purposes. Additionally, there is an adjustment to the limitation on room and board distributions for qualified higher education expenses. The amendment to Section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code includes first cousins as family members for educational savings. There is also an adjustment to the limitation on room and board distributions for qualified higher education expenses. The institution is charged for room and board costs for a specific period. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
